src_text: Tete Egypt Ahennie foforoɔ no ho dwiriw wɔn wɔ adidifoɔ no ahoni no ho, na na ɛda so yɛ kama ɛmfa ho sɛ edi mfe ɔpepem no.
ref_text: New Kingdom ancient Egyptians marvelled at their predecessors monuments, which were then well over a thousand year old.
hyp_text: The Egyptian New Kingdom was established around 1550 BCE, following a period of foreign rule by the Hyksos during the Second Intermediate Period. The New Kingdom saw Egypt attempt to create a buffer and level of security from invading foreign armies (i.e. the Hittites from the north; the Hyksos from the northeast; and the Nubians from the south) by extending its boarders and attempting to gain control of neighboring areas. It marked the resurgence of the Egyptian empire, which for period became the preeminent power in the Near East. The New Kingdom, during the 18th, 19th, and 20th dynasties (1550–1077 BCE), saw Egypt's power reach its peak. It expanded far into Nubia in the south, and held wide territories in the Near East. Egyptian armies fought Hittite armies for control of modern-day Syria. Three of the best known pharaohs of the New Kingdom are Akhenaten, also known as Amenhotep IV, whose exclusive worship of the Aten is often interpreted as the first instance of monotheism, Tutankhamun, especially known for the artifacts discovered in his nearly intact tomb, and Ramesses II, who attempted to recover the territories in modern Israel/Palestine, Lebanon and Syria that had been held in the Eighteenth Dynasty. His reconquest led to the Battle of Qadesh, where he led Egyptian armies against those of the Hittite king Muwatalli II. Though the battle ended in a stalemate, the Egyptian and Hittite forces signed the earliest known peace treaty a few years later. Around 1350 BC, the stability of the New Kingdom was threatened by the forces of the Habiru, who may have been the Hebrews. They had already been used by Egypt as mercenaries (as recorded by both Egyptian and Hittite sources). The Habiru were not defeated outright, and some may have settled in the Egyptian delta. This was the time of the Apiru, a probably related theocratic society known to have existed in what is today Iraq and Syria, practicing a somewhat different religion of Aton. Towards the end of the New Kingdom, the pharaohs of the Twenty-first Dynasty reasserted their authority only in Upper Egypt. This brought them into constant conflict with the Twenty-second Dynasty of the High Priests of Amun, who were then the effective rulers of Lower Egypt. The High Priests became pharaohs of the Twenty-second Dynasty. Meanwhile, the Libyans had settled in the Western Delta, and a related foreign people, the Sea Peoples, had invaded the Delta from the north and the Nile valley. The Egyptian army and diplomacy of the last pharaoh of the New Kingdom, Ramesses III, allowed Egypt to weather this crisis, repelled the invaders, and prevented the collapse of the empire. A pivot point in Egyptian history, this epoch witnessed the slow decline into the Third Intermediate Period.
